title: Iowa Farmers Stick With Trump Despite Trade War
summary: President's trade battle with China has hit Farm Belt hard, but not his support in heavily rural area. DES MOINES, Iowa-As President Trump maps out his re-election bid, farmers in this battleground state are backing him even with the U.S. Farm Belt bracing for deeper pain from his trade fight with China.

title: WeWork IPO Filing Shows Revenue Growth, Wide Losses
summary: We generated $1.54 billion in revenue in the first six months of 2019 and posted a net loss of $689.7 million. WeWork's parent company unveiled the papers for its initial public offering, depicting a business whose revenue-and losses-are ballooning.

title: The Navarro Recession, II
summary: Evidence of a tariff-inspired slowdown spooks the markets.. After we warned last week that U.S. trade policy was courting recession, White House aide Peter Navarro took to Fox Business to denounce us for sounding like The People's Daily, the Chinese Communist propaganda arm. That was novel as criticisms of these columns go, but perhaps Mr. Navarro would care to comment again after Wednesday's recession warning from the bond and equity markets? Are they Commies too?

title: Bernie's Medicare-for-All Bailout
summary: Sanders wants taxpayers to save hospitals after he bankrupts them.. Usually politicians pass a bailout to clean up a mess they've created in the past, but Bernie Sanders is now promising cash up front. Witness the democratic socialist's opening offer to the hospitals he'd bankrupt with his Medicare-for-All bill.

title: The Kansas-Missouri Subsidy Armistice
summary: Two states agree to quit shuffling jobs back and forth across the border.. A destructive economic "border war" between Kansas and Missouri may now be ending in an overdue truce. For years the two states have spent millions on tax incentives to lure jobs back and forth across the state line in Kansas City.

title: Federal Monitor Finds Problems With PG&E Tree-Trimming Program
summary: Oversight team says spot check raises concerns about company's efforts to reduce wildfire risks. A federal court monitor overseeing PG&E Corp.'s probation has uncovered serious problems with the company's effort to trim trees to reduce the risk they will hit nearby power lines and spark wildfires.

title: Argentina's Race to the Bottom
summary: Investors flee on the prospect of a return of the Peronists to power.. Does Argentina have a death wish? That's the question going around after Peronist Alberto Fernández and his running mate, former President Cristina Kirchner, took first place in Sunday's presidential "primaries" with 48% of the vote. President Mauricio Macri finished 16 points behind, suggesting slim re-election prospects for the center-right politician.

title: Britons Worry No-Deal Brexit Will Cause Drug Shortages
summary: Three-quarters of medicines consumed in U.K. arrive through narrow English Channel crossing, so any bottlenecks could quickly squeeze drug stocks. LONDON-As the U.K. prepared to leave the European Union this spring, Carl Foster worried that an abrupt split would snarl British ports, preventing him from getting the imported epilepsy drug he needs.

title: Does Hong Kong Matter?
summary: Trump should know better than anyone that these protests in Hong Kong are about freedom.. Walking across the White House lawn a few weeks ago on his way to an event in Ohio, President Trump was asked by a reporter about the protests in Hong Kong. They have been constant since June, when authorities were about to pass a law that would have allowed Hong Kong residents and even foreign nationals to be extradited to the mainland for prosecution under China's legal system.

title: Viacom-CBS Merger Could Boost Advertising Ambitions
summary: Tie-up is poised to fuel new ad technology and ad-supported streaming video. The merger of CBS Corp. and Viacom Inc. creates a larger media company better positioned to pursue advanced advertising technology and ad-supported streaming video.

title: Eric Holder Urges Judges to Vote Democratic
summary: The justices rejected his flawed argument, but he presses on with it in state court.. Most U.S. attorneys general avoid partisan politics after leaving office. That's not the case with Eric Holder. In 2016 Mr. Holder, who headed the Justice Department under President Obama from 2009-15, formed the National Democratic Redistricting Committee, ostensibly to combat gerrymandering. In reality, it's a power play. The nation's former chief law-enforcement officer wants to guarantee that Democrats control redistricting in 2021, when states redraw congressional and state legislative districts after next year's census.

title: Modern Monetary Theory Is Ancient
summary: The Greeks and Romans tried it. Would that they had been the last.. With the presidential campaign under way, expect to hear a lot more about a shiny new toy of progressive economic thinking, "modern monetary theory." It seems to be the only intellectual contortion that might allow candidates to promise virtually unlimited government spending without any deleterious effects on America's currency, standard of living or liberty.

title: 'Fraud in the Lab' Review: Experiments in Doubt
summary: Lapses of rigor, misleading methods, outright falsiﬁcation: How common are the transgressions of research scientists?. Scientific misconduct is surely as old as scientific inquiry, but in the modern era the mainstream media took little notice of it before 1974. In that year, it flagged the case of a medical researcher at Memorial Sloan Kettering in New York who used a felt-tip pen to darken patches of purportedly black skin transplanted onto white mice. Within a couple of years, separately, the British psychologist Cyril Burt was posthumously found to have invented data to support his theory that IQ was largely inherited.

summary: Demonstrators adapt their tactics, betting Beijing will decide a crackdown would cost it too much.. Hong Kong

summary: Networking giant's forecast wasn't that bleak, but timing was bad. For Cisco , being a prettier house in a bad neighborhood isn't enough.

summary: Several complaints named Archdiocese of New York, one of nation's largest Catholic dioceses, as defendant. Attorneys representing alleged victims of child sexual abuse filed hundreds of lawsuits in courts across New York state Wednesday, the first day of a one-year window when people who said they were abused as children can bring civil suits.

title: ObamaCare's Medicaid Deception
summary: States cover millions who exceed income thresholds, some quite well-heeled.. ObamaCare wasn't supposed to give free health insurance to everybody. The Affordable Care Act's authors expected the poor would enroll in Medicaid, while those with higher incomes would buy coverage through the new insurance exchanges, with subsidies that decrease as income rises.

title: FDA Approves New Pill for Drug-Resistant TB
summary: Pretomanid would be taken with two other pills to treat highly treatment-resistant tuberculosis. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration approved a new drug to help treat deadly, drug-resistant forms of tuberculosis, the world's biggest infectious-disease killer.

title: Three Political Truths the Democrats Can't Handle
summary: Many voters find their trade policies, Medicare for All and the Green New Deal too radical.. In my book "Hard Heads, Soft Hearts" (1987), I bemoaned that it was difficult to be both a Democrat and an economist. Democrats, I wrote, often advocated economic policies that were well-intentioned but softheaded. Yes, ends matter, but so do means.

title: Donald vs. Boris? Try 'Arugula' vs. 'Rocket'
summary: Despite globalization, amusing-and baffling-differences between American and British English still exist.. Is globalization reducing the difference between American and British English? In London recently, I noticed that the menu in a gastropub featured "cumberland sausages, mashed potatoes, and onion gravy." This used to be called bangers and mash. Yet there still are many different English words for foods. The English call zucchini "courgette" and arugula "rocket." There are also different names for types of vehicles, including the stroller, which the English call a "push-chair."

summary: The $2.35 billion deal marks the highest price paid for a U.S. professional sports franchise. Alibaba Group Holding Ltd. co-founder Joseph Tsai is close to a deal to become majority owner of the National Basketball Association's Brooklyn Nets.

title: Why Brad Falchuk Is Hollywood's Best-Kept Secret
summary: The press-shy man behind Ryan Murphy-and husband to Gwyneth Paltrow-has signed a major production deal of his own with Netflix. How the writer-producer-director, out with 'The Politician,' is carving his own path. On the second floor of Building 12 on the Fox Studios lot in the Century City section of Los Angeles, home to Ryan Murphy Television, Brad Falchuk's office sits beside that of his mentor Murphy, who first hired him as a junior writer on Nip/Tuck in 2003 and with whom he has worked on more than a half dozen series, including Glee, American Horror Story, American Crime Story, Scream Queens and Pose. The two workspaces are similar in size and décor. However, one contains a trove of Boston Red Sox and Bruce Springsteen memorabilia and Falchuk himself, a trim, muscular man in a white V-neck tee, paint-spattered carpenter pants and work boots, who straightens a stack of scripts before making his way to a story meeting.

title: Oil Tumbles on Renewed Demand Worries
summary: Crude follows stocks lower on fresh global-growth fears. Oil prices slid on Wednesday, falling alongside stocks and other risky assets, after downbeat economic news from China and Germany fueled fresh worries about a slowdown in global growth.

title: The Dollar, Yuan and Paper Currency Tigers
summary: How odd that the day after the dollar price of gold surged above $1,500 per ounce you contend that President Trump's uneven policies had been contributing to "a rising dollar.". How odd that the day after the dollar price of gold surged above $1,500 per ounce you contend that President Trump's uneven policies had been contributing to "a rising dollar" ("A Navarro Recession?" Review & Outlook, Aug. 8). Not mentioned was that the dollar, like the euro, yen, pound and every other global currency floats thanks to what George Melloan once described as "an absence of policy."

title: U.S. Really Doesn't Need Democracy Abroad
summary: I say no! We have been down that road before and we have nothing to show for it. The Iraq fiasco and the Afghanistan scene have shown little promise of democracy.. To William A. Galston's "'America First' Needs Democracy Abroad" (Politics & Ideas, Aug. 7), I say no! We have been down that road before and we have nothing to show for it. The Iraq fiasco and the Afghanistan scene have shown little promise of democracy, and who is to say that the Taliban will not rule once we leave. It's a myth that we need other countries to be democratic for our democracy to survive. It's perhaps more likely that democratic societies would be less likely to go to war with each other but even that is a supposition.

title: Trump Polarizes Perception As Well as National Policy
summary: Mr. Trump's supporters take him seriously but not literally, while his detractors take him literally but not seriously.. Gerald F. Seib's admittedly rough attempt to divide Americans into three broad categories when it comes to their views of President Trump misses at least one significant one. ("President Confronts a Bitter Divide," U.S. News, Aug. 6.) My own unscientific survey suggests that there are a great many Americans who endorse many of the president's policies, including tax reform, deregulation initiatives, standing up to China, and even occasionally ham-handed diplomacy with North Korea and Iran, but are personally embarrassed by his lack of decorum and polarizing language, even if much is discounted as being for effect. During the 2016 election, a political analyst made an insightful observation that has only been reinforced over time: Mr. Trump's supporters take him seriously but not literally, while his detractors take him literally but not seriously. Unfortunately, the Democratic primary season seems determined to deny us a welcome alternative.

title: Hot-Car Deaths Aren't Manufacturer's Fault
summary: The problem of babies and pets left alone to die in a hot car originates between the steering wheel and the driver's seat. No legislation or sensor technology can enforce presence of mind.. Your article "Child Advocates Join With PETA, Others on Hot-Car Deaths" (Life & Arts, Aug. 8) should have questioned why those organizations are lobbying for federal legislation that would mandate car companies to resolve a problem that their cars do not create. The problem of babies and pets left alone to die in a hot car originates between the steering wheel and the driver's seat. No legislation or sensor technology can enforce presence of mind. Why aren't People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals and child-safety advocates satisfied with public education campaigns, or the new sensors being developed, as the article noted, by companies such as Sense a Life Corp.? Because these advocacy groups need to demonstrate their relevance through the number of laws they push through. Ford and GM should have the spine to point out that they build cars that are safe to the extent that car owners assume the responsibility that they agreed to take on when they became guardians of a living being. Requiring car companies to alert owners of a living being left in their car will add cost to the production of a car, divert funds from other research and add costly red tape to show compliance.

title: Toni Morrison Expanded The Imagination of Many
summary: I will forever be grateful for her vision, bravery and artistry.. I had the honor of producing a photo shoot with Toni Morrison for Essence magazine, where I was fashion director, many moons ago. ("'Beloved' Novelist Dies at 88," Life & Arts, Aug. 7.) She was regal then, as always. Years before, as a student at Howard University, I learned that she had been a student and then a teacher there before my arrival. I discovered her genius in an English class when I read "The Bluest Eye." Her vision and understanding of the intricacies of black culture opened my eyes and made me see us through a new lens.

title: Why The Hoop Earring Continues to Reign Supreme
summary: Hoops can be traced back thousands of years, yet the circular earrings continue to be a jewelry-box staple. How designers are embracing and updating them for fashionable women today. IS IT A TREND if it never goes away? That's the koan posed by the hoop earring-a shape that's been a continual presence in jewelry for thousands of years and yet has buzzily gained prominence over the past few. (Zendaya's appearance in a saucer-sized pair at the Louis Vuitton 2017 resort collection did a lot to make that happen.) They were a standout accessory at several spring and fall shows, thanks to designers like Valentino creative director Pierpaolo Piccioli and Stella McCartney, who partnered with the textile artist Sheila Hicks to create large, fiber-wrapped hoops.

title: Portland, Maine: An Incomparable Insider's Guide
summary: The Maine seaport delivers all the ingredients for a late-summer escape-and then some. Novelist Richard Russo and three other savvy locals share their favorite seafood restaurants, hotel bars and island day trips. JAMES BEARD AWARD-WINNING RESTAURANTS line cobblestone streets, breweries turn out serious suds and the lobster roll is in a constant state of upscale reinvention. Portland, Maine, is a food-lover's fantasyland, but the culture goes well beyond the plate. Works by Renoir, Homer and Picasso hang at the Portland Museum of Art, and Mother Nature puts on an all-seasons show. Set on the water-the Casco Bay islands make for picturesque day trips-the former capital of the state is rife with trails winding through its parks and promenades. Visitors are prone to mid-hike epiphanies: Why not live here? Soon after novelist Richard Russo and his wife, Barbara, moved to town, daughters Kate and Emily followed. Emily opened PRINT, a bookstore in artsy Munjoy Hill. "Our roots in Portland are very deep," said Mr. Russo, whose new book, "Chances Are..." was written there. "I can't think what would get us out of here now."

title: Is Your Jeanneret a Fake?
summary: Chairs by the iconic Swiss designer Pierre Jeanneret fetch tens of thousands at auction. But which are real? With no foundation to police his trademark, provenance (and who's profiting) are often blurry. A wild design caper that touches on issues of authenticity, integrity and legacy. While swiping through images on an iPad, interior designer Billy Cotton recalls the process of hunting down furnishings for the project on-screen, a family home he's finishing up not far from his office in downtown Brooklyn. A banquette stretching to diving-board length slides by, followed by a cluster of '50s chairs against a wall of abstract paintings. In the living room, a cube-shaped fireplace is flanked by a pair of vintage armchairs by the Swiss architect Pierre Jeanneret, their teak frames blanketed in loden green cowhide. When he gets to a shot of the study, Cotton stops. He pinches and zooms to highlight a desk the color of butterscotch with compass-style legs: another piece by Jeanneret.

title: These Are the Most Exclusive Teas in the World. Fancy a Cup?
summary: Furnishing the high teas at Claridge's in London and other five-star dining rooms, the Rare Tea Company started 15 years ago in Henrietta Lovell's apartment. Inside their origin story (and the best teas they make). Henrietta Lovell travels like an old-fashioned door-to-door salesman, toting a compact handled case stocked with the tools of her trade. Inside are loose-leaf teas, ethically grown and personally sourced from some of the world's most remote regions.

title: Hong Kong Tightens Airport Security After Days of Protests
summary: Only passengers were allowed into terminals after a dayslong occupation that caused travel chaos in the busy hub. HONG KONG-Authorities on Wednesday stepped up security to bar protesters from entering the airport, a day after violent clashes between police and pro-democracy demonstrators paralyzed one of the world's busiest travel hubs.

title: Trump Advisers Are Wary as President Considers Gun Proposals
summary: Following mass shootings, Trump is interested in exploring legislation with new gun restrictions, but his aides are divided on the right approach. WASHINGTON-President Trump's public push for gun-control measures is causing consternation among conservatives and some of his advisers, who have privately raised concerns about the political and policy fallout of the approach, according to White House officials and people familiar with the discussions.

title: This CEO Wants to Extract Rare Earths From Trade Fight
summary: Amanda Lacaze's small company is working to break up China's dominance in the sector.. The rare-earths company that Amanda Lacaze runs is small, but her mission is immense: weaning the West off its dependence on China for the obscure metals needed in high-tech gear including cellphones, electric cars and jet fighters.

title: U.S. Retreat on New Tariffs Gives Beijing Breathing Room on Trade Talks
summary: Decision keeps trade war from escalating as Chinese economy flashes warning signs. BEIJING-The Trump administration's move to postpone the imposition of tariffs on $156 billion in Chinese goods is being regarded in Beijing as a step toward detente, Chinese experts say, increasing the likelihood that China sends negotiators to attend scheduled face-to-face trade talks in September.

title: Museum of Ice Cream Valued at $200 Million
summary: Ice cream-themed attraction plans expansion of branded food and products. Venture investors are valuing the company behind the Museum of Ice Cream at $200 million in a bet that the frozen dessert-themed attraction can expand further into branded food, products-and a new theme beyond ice cream.

title: Investors Heart Edwards Lifesciences
summary: Shares of the cardiovascular-focused company have surged this year, but they have more room to run if a new procedure catches on. Edwards Lifesciences has sent pulses racing recently, but only in a good way.

title: For Women in Business, It's All About Critical Mass
summary: Companies and boards with many women, not just token females, may outperform. One small step into the corner office by a female executive could mean a giant leap for a firm's bottom line, depending on how she gets her foot in the door.

title: More U.S. Companies Consider Outside CFO Candidates
summary: UPS, Ford and Intel all hired outside finance chiefs in recent months, highlighting a wider trend among American companies. U.S. businesses across a range of sectors increasingly are turning to outsiders to fill finance chief vacancies, with the percentage of businesses seeking CFOs from beyond their ranks reaching a decade high.

title: AI Startup Boom Raises Questions of Exaggerated Tech Savvy
summary: SoftBank-backed startup offers 'human-assisted' artificial-intelligence; current, former employees say company inflates its tech expertise. Startup Engineer.ai says it uses artificial-intelligence technology to largely automate the development of mobile apps, but several current and former employees say the company exaggerates its AI capabilities to attract customers and investors.

title: Battle Emerges Over Nuclear Waste in America's Oil Patch
summary: Proposal to put atomic-waste site in Permian Basin moves forward as opponents worry about threat to valuable U.S. oil fields. A plan to build two big nuclear-waste storage facilities in the heart of the most important U.S. oil field is igniting a fight between frackers and the atomic-energy industry.

title: The Moment a Hong Kong Policeman Pulled His Gun on Protesters
summary: A WSJ video shows an embattled officer pulling his sidearm to chase off assailants. Here's how a day that began with a quiet protest got to that point.. On Tuesday night, at the doors to the airport's Terminal 1, Hong Kong came within seconds of tragedy.

title: The Good News Behind China's Dreadful Economic Numbers
summary: Any sign that China is weaning itself off unsustainable credit booms deserves some celebration. If China is opening the financial floodgates to counter a domestic slowdown and escalating trade tensions, there's no sign of it in July's feeble data.

title: U.S. to Back More Condo Loans Aimed at First-Time Buyers
summary: Move expands FHA-backed low-down-payment loans in loosening of crisis-era rules. The Trump administration is vastly expanding the scope of condominium purchases eligible for lower-down-payment loans.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Fannie, Freddie to Consider Alternatives to FICO Scores
summary: Housing-finance regulator aims to shake-up credit scores for mortgages. WASHINGTON-One firm's dominance over the credit scores used to vet many U.S. mortgages is getting a shake-up.

title: Geopolitical Faux Pas Prompts Foreign Brands to Apologize to China Consumers
summary: Luxury brands like Versace and Coach had labeled Hong Kong as a separate entity from the mainland, prompting Chinese backlash. BEIJING-Foreign companies that have been labeling Hong Kong as a separate entity from China were quick to apologize this week to angry Chinese buyers, fearful of losing favor in the world's second-biggest consumer market.

title: Hong Kong Protesters, Police Clash at Airport
summary: Protesters battle with police on second day of snarled travel plans. HONG KONG-Police clashed with protesters thronging Hong Kong's airport late Tuesday, with violence flaring at the end of a second straight day of pro-democracy demonstrators overwhelming one of the world's busiest travel hubs.

title: Jail Staffers Guarding Epstein's Unit Placed on Leave
summary: Warden of New York detention facility was reassigned as Justice Department continues probe. Two jail staffers who were guarding Jeffrey Epstein's unit the night he died were placed on leave Tuesday, and the warden of the New York detention facility was reassigned as the Justice Department intensified its investigation of the disgraced financier's death.

title: Dayton Police Provide Minute-by-Minute Timeline of Shooting
summary: Officers processed security-camera footage to build detailed account of events. Police in Dayton, Ohio, provided the first minute-by-minute timeline of gunman Connor Betts's short rampage that left nine dead and 17 others injured, but remain stumped by questions about motive and whether he intended to shoot his sister.

title: New York City Teachers Get 'Culturally Responsive' Training
summary: They are exploring ways to help public-school students of all backgrounds see themselves in their lessons. About 200 New York City teachers gathered in East Harlem on Tuesday to explore how to make computer-science classes "culturally responsive."
